tn.text: This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Samuel gives information about the war between David and the supporters of Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Here "house" is used to mean "supporters."
This metaphor means the number of people supporting David increased. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This metaphor means the number of people supporting Saul's family decreased. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "David's wives gave birth to six sons" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is the numerical order of David's sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
These are women's names. They are the wives of David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: fourth son ... fifth son ... the sixth
tn.text: This is the numerical order of David's sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
These are the names of David's sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of David's wives. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This introduces a new event in the story of the struggle between David's supporters and Saul's family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
This refers to Saul's family and supporters who assumed control of his estate after he died.
This refers to the supporters of David.

tn.ref: Abner made himself strong in the house of Saul
tn.text: Abner's increasing power over Saul's family is spoken of as if he became physically stronger. AT: "Abner gained more power over the family and supporters of Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These are names of women. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a male name, a son of Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Why have you slept with my father's concubine?
tn.text: Ishbosheth asked this question to rebuke Abner who was acting like he was the king. AT: "You did not have the right to sleep with my father's concubine!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a euphemism for sexual relations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: Am I a dog's head that belongs to Judah?
tn.text: This question is used by Abner as an angry denial of Ishbosheth's accusation. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "I am not a traitor working for David!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Am I a dog's head that belongs to Judah?
tn.text: Abner speaks of himself as the head of a dog, which the Israelites considered to be loyal to anyone who fed them. Here "belongs to Judah" implies that Abner's loyalty is to Judah, to which David belonged, and not to Saul's house. AT: "Am I a traitor for Judah?" or "I am not a traitor working for David!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hand" represents the power to defeat. AT: "to be defeated by David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: But now you accuse me of an offense concerning this woman?
tn.text: Abner asks this question to rebuke Ishbosheth. It is unclear if Abner actually slept with Rizpah, or if he was falsely accused. Possible meanings are 1) Abner was guilty. AT: "You should not be upset that I slept with this woman!" or 2) Abner was not guilty. AT: "You should not think that I have slept with this woman!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: May God do so to me ... and more also, if I do not
tn.text: This is the form of a solemn vow in that time. Abner is asking God to judge him severely if he does not keep his vow. Your language may have a way of expressing vows. AT: "I am asking God to punish me if I do not"
Here "house" refers to Saul's family and supporters who survived Saul's death. AT: "the family and supporters of Saul"
This phrase refers to the authority of David as king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Some versions add "when he was at Hebron" and others omit it. You may want to add the phrase if it is present in your national version. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_textvariants]])

The original text of this question is not clear. Possible meanings are 1) Abner had the power to give the land to David. AT: "This land is mine!" or 2) David is chosen by God to rule the land: AT: "This land rightfully belongs to you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "hand" represents Abner's assistance that he is offering to David. AT: "I will assist you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you cannot see my face unless you first bring Michal
tn.text: David is stating the condition under which he will meet Abner. Here "face" refers to David himself. AT: "you cannot see me unless you bring Michal to me first" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is the name of a daughter of Saul. She was David's first wife. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This represents the number of men David killed so that Saul would allow him to marry Michal. The "foreskin" is the fold of skin that covers the male reproductive organ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Paltiel was Michal's second husband. Saul gave her to him after David fled from Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a village. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"So now make David your king"

tn.ref: By the hand of my servant David
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to David's power to defeat the Philistines. AT: "I will empower my servant David and" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hand" refers to power over Israel. AT: "the power of the Philistines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the hand of all their enemies
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to power over Israel. AT: "the power of all of their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the people of Benjamin ... the whole house of Benjamin
tn.text: Both of these statements refer to the descendants of Benjamin, who were one of the tribes of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The number of men who came with Abner. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This phrase means "all of the nation of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
They parted as friends. David was not angry with Abner.
These are items taken from the enemy.

tn.ref: Abner was not with David in Hebron
tn.text: Abner had already left to return home.
"someone told Joab"
This is a man's name. He is the grandfather of Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Joab asks this question to rebuke David for letting Abner go in peace. AT: "You should not have done this!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why have you sent him away, and he is gone?
tn.text: Joab asks this question to rebuke David for letting Abner escape. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Abner was here and you let him leave!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Do you not know ... everything you are doing?
tn.text: Joab asks this question to convince David that Abner is plotting against David. AT: "Surely you know ... everything you are doing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"Sirah" is the name of a place where the well was located. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This refers to one of the gates in the city wall at Hebron. As the UDB implies, city gates were constructed as part of buildings set into the city walls. Inside the passageway were doors leading to side rooms, where guests could be received and business and judicial proceedings could be conducted. It was probably in one of these rooms that Joab murdered Abner.
Here "blood" is associated with the death of Asahel. AT: "the death of Asahel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a male person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

Here "blood" refers to the death of Abner. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:03:27|3:27]]. AT: "the death of Abner" or "the murder of Abner" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: fall on the head of Joab and on all his father's house
tn.text: This phrase means the results of the guilt will happen to Joab and his family as if something heavy had collapsed on them. AT: "always cause suffering for Joab and for all his father's house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "house" refers to descendants. AT: "all the descendants of Joab's father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: May there never fail to be
tn.text: This double negative emphasizes that there will always be someone with the problems listed. AT: "May there always be" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "sword" refers to violent death. AT: "dies violently" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"is hungry"

tn.ref: Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth
tn.text: These were symbolic actions to demonstrate their grief and sadness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: The king wept and cried loudly
tn.text: The words "wept" and "cried loudly" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how much David mourned for Abner. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Should Abner die as a fool dies?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is used to emphasize that his death was not fair. AT: "Abner should not have died in disgrace!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Your hands were not bound. Your feet were not shackled
tn.text: These two sentences express similar ideas. They can be combined into one sentence.  AT: "You were in no way a criminal in prison" or "You were completely innocent of doing wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "No one had tied your hands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "No one had attached your feet to chains" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to people who are unjust or wicked. AT: "wicked men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This deliberate exaggeration is used to show that the nation of Israel wanted to take care of David in his grief. AT: "Many people came" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: May God do so to me, and more also, if
tn.text: This is the form of a solemn vow in that time. David is asking God to judge him severely if he eats anything before sunset. Your language many have a way of expressing vows. AT: "I am asking God to punish me if"

tn.ref: Do you not know that a prince and a great man has fallen this day in Israel?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is used to show how much David respected Abner. Here "fallen" is a euphemism that means "died." It can be translated as a statement. AT: "It is certainly true that a great prince has died today in Israel!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: a prince and a great man
tn.text: These two phrases both refer to Abner. AT: "a great prince" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"without mercy"
